title: Acts Chapter 13 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Acts chapter 13 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Acts Chapter 13 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Acts Chapter 13.

questions.question: Who were some of the prophets and teachers in the church at Antioch?
options: Barnabas, Simeon called Niger, Lucius of Cyrene, Manaen, and Saul
questions.correctAnswer: Barnabas, Simeon called Niger, Lucius of Cyrene, Manaen, and Saul
questions.explanation: Acts 13:1 lists Barnabas, Simeon called Niger, Lucius of Cyrene, Manaen, and Saul as prophets and teachers in the church at Antioch.

questions.question: What did the Holy Ghost say when the prophets and teachers ministered and fasted?
options: Separate me Barnabas and Saul for the work whereunto I have called them
questions.correctAnswer: Separate me Barnabas and Saul for the work whereunto I have called them
questions.explanation: Acts 13:2 states that the Holy Ghost said, 'Separate me Barnabas and Saul for the work whereunto I have called them.'

questions.question: Where did Barnabas and Saul sail to after departing from Seleucia?
questions.correctAnswer: Cyprus
questions.explanation: Acts 13:4 says they departed unto Seleucia and from thence sailed to Cyprus.

questions.question: Who was the minister that traveled with Barnabas and Saul while they preached in the synagogues of the Jews?
questions.correctAnswer: John
questions.explanation: Acts 13:5 mentions that John was their minister while Barnabas and Saul preached in the synagogues.

questions.question: What was the name of the sorcerer and false prophet they encountered in Paphos?
questions.correctAnswer: Barjesus
questions.explanation: Acts 13:6 identifies the sorcerer and false prophet as Barjesus.

questions.question: Who was the deputy of the country that desired to hear the word of God?
questions.correctAnswer: Sergius Paulus
questions.explanation: Acts 13:7 describes Sergius Paulus as the prudent deputy who called for Barnabas and Saul to hear the word of God.

questions.question: What happened to Elymas the sorcerer when Paul looked at him?
questions.correctAnswer: He was struck with blindness
questions.explanation: Acts 13:11 says Elymas was struck with blindness, mist and darkness fell on him immediately after Paul's rebuke.

questions.question: True or False: John continued to travel with Paul and Barnabas throughout their journey after Perga.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Acts 13:13 states John departed from them and returned to Jerusalem after they left Perga.

questions.question: Where did Paul and his company go after departing from Perga?
questions.correctAnswer: Antioch in Pisidia
questions.explanation: Acts 13:14 says they came to Antioch in Pisidia after departing Perga.

questions.question: What did the rulers of the synagogue say after reading the law and the prophets?
options: If you have any word of exhortation for the people, say on
questions.correctAnswer: If you have any word of exhortation for the people, say on
questions.explanation: Acts 13:15 records the rulers of the synagogue inviting Paul and Barnabas to speak words of exhortation.

questions.question: Who did Paul say was raised up to be the king after Saul was removed?
questions.correctAnswer: David
questions.explanation: Acts 13:22 says God raised up David to be their king after removing Saul.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'Of this man's seed hath God according to his promise raised unto Israel a ______.'
questions.correctAnswer: Saviour
questions.explanation: Acts 13:23 states that God raised unto Israel a Saviour from this man's seed.

questions.question: What was John's message about the one who was coming after him?
options: He is mightier and I am not worthy to loose his shoes
He will build a great kingdom
He is a prophet like me
He will bring war to the land
questions.correctAnswer: He is mightier and I am not worthy to loose his shoes
questions.explanation: Acts 13:25 says John said he was not the one but that one coming after him is mightier, and he is not worthy to loose his shoes.

questions.question: True or False: The Jews and their rulers in Jerusalem knew Jesus and accepted him without condemnation.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Acts 13:27 states that the Jews and their rulers did not know Jesus and condemned him, fulfilling the prophets' words.

questions.question: What did Paul and Barnabas do when the Jews rejected the word of God?
questions.correctAnswer: Turned to the Gentiles
questions.explanation: Acts 13:46 says Paul and Barnabas turned to the Gentiles after the Jews rejected the word of God.

medium.title: Acts Chapter 13 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Acts Chapter 13 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with understanding God's call on their life. Based on Acts 13, what biblical truth would you share about discerning God's calling?
options: God calls and separates individuals through the Holy Spirit during prayer and fasting
God calls only through dreams and visions
God calls through worldly success and popularity
God calls only through church elders' approval
questions.correctAnswer: God calls and separates individuals through the Holy Spirit during prayer and fasting
questions.explanation: Acts 13:2 shows that as the church ministered and fasted, the Holy Spirit spoke and separated Barnabas and Saul for their work. This teaches that God's calling is discerned through prayer, fasting, and the guidance of the Holy Spirit.

questions.question: How does Acts 13 teach us about the importance of spiritual preparation before ministry or evangelism?
options: By fasting, praying, and laying hands before sending out workers
By immediately starting work without preparation
By relying only on human wisdom and planning
By seeking approval from political leaders first
questions.correctAnswer: By fasting, praying, and laying hands before sending out workers
questions.explanation: Acts 13:3 describes how Barnabas and Saul were sent off after fasting, praying, and the laying on of hands, emphasizing the need for spiritual preparation and dependence on God before ministry.

questions.question: A believer is facing opposition while sharing the Gospel. According to Acts 13, what attitude should they adopt when confronted by resistance?
options: Be bold and continue to preach the word of God
Change the message to please everyone
Rely on political power to enforce belief
questions.correctAnswer: Be bold and continue to preach the word of God
questions.explanation: Acts 13:46 shows Paul and Barnabas boldly speaking to the Jews despite opposition, teaching perseverance and courage in evangelism even when faced with rejection.

questions.question: What does Acts 13 teach about humility and recognizing the role of Jesus in salvation?
options: Jesus is the Savior raised according to God's promise
Salvation comes through human effort alone
Salvation is only for certain ethnic groups
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus is the Savior raised according to God's promise
questions.explanation: Acts 13:23 clearly states that God raised Jesus as a Savior according to His promise, highlighting the humility required to acknowledge Jesus as the source of salvation rather than relying on human achievements.

questions.question: How does Acts 13 illustrate the value of evangelism to all people, including Gentiles?
options: The Gospel is a light to the Gentiles and salvation to the ends of the earth
Evangelism should be limited to certain groups only
Gentiles are excluded from the message of salvation
Only Jews are responsible for spreading the Gospel
questions.correctAnswer: The Gospel is a light to the Gentiles and salvation to the ends of the earth
questions.explanation: Acts 13:47 shows that the Lord commanded Paul and Barnabas to be a light of the Gentiles for salvation to the ends of the earth, teaching inclusiveness in evangelism.

questions.question: A believer is discouraged after rejection by their own community. Based on Acts 13, what biblical principle encourages them to keep going?
options: Shake off rejection and continue to move forward in obedience
Seek revenge on those who reject them
Change the message to be more acceptable
questions.correctAnswer: Shake off rejection and continue to move forward in obedience
questions.explanation: Acts 13:51 describes Paul and Barnabas shaking off the dust from their feet after rejection and going to another city, showing the importance of perseverance without bitterness.

questions.question: What does Acts 13 teach about the role of the Holy Spirit in empowering believers for ministry?
options: The Holy Spirit fills and guides believers to boldly witness
The Holy Spirit is not involved in everyday ministry
Ministry depends solely on human effort
Only select leaders receive the Holy Spirit
questions.correctAnswer: The Holy Spirit fills and guides believers to boldly witness
questions.explanation: Acts 13:9 and Acts 13:52 show Paul filled with the Holy Spirit confronting opposition and the disciples being filled with joy and the Holy Spirit, emphasizing the Spirit's role in empowerment.

questions.question: True or False: Acts 13 teaches that forgiveness of sins is offered through Jesus Christ.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Acts 13:38 clearly states that through Jesus is preached the forgiveness of sins, teaching the foundational Christian truth about salvation and forgiveness.

questions.question: True or False: According to Acts 13, the Jewish leaders accepted Jesus as the promised Savior without opposition.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Acts 13:27-28 shows that the Jewish rulers did not recognize Jesus and sought his death, indicating their opposition rather than acceptance.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Paul said that God removed Saul and raised up _______ to be king, a man after God's own heart.
questions.correctAnswer: David
questions.explanation: Acts 13:22 states God removed Saul and raised up David, a man after His own heart, demonstrating God's sovereign choice and purpose.

questions.question: How does Acts 13 encourage believers to respond when sharing the Gospel leads to jealousy and persecution?
options: Continue faithfully and trust God despite opposition
Stop sharing the Gospel to avoid persecution
Seek to please persecutors to gain favor
questions.correctAnswer: Continue faithfully and trust God despite opposition
questions.explanation: Acts 13:45-50 describes the Jews' envy leading to persecution, yet Paul and Barnabas continued their mission, teaching faithfulness amidst trials.

questions.question: What practical lesson about church leadership and service can be drawn from the example of prophets and teachers at Antioch in Acts 13?
options: Church leaders serve together in prayer, fasting, and mutual support
Leadership is based on personal ambition
Only one person should lead without counsel
questions.correctAnswer: Church leaders serve together in prayer, fasting, and mutual support
questions.explanation: Acts 13:1-3 shows prophets and teachers gathered, praying and fasting together before sending out Barnabas and Saul, highlighting teamwork and spiritual discipline in leadership.

questions.question: According to Acts 13, what is a key biblical principle about faith and trust in God's promises?
options: God fulfills His promises by raising Jesus from the dead for believers' hope
God's promises are conditional on human works alone
Promises should be doubted without immediate evidence
Faith is irrelevant to receiving God's promises
questions.correctAnswer: God fulfills His promises by raising Jesus from the dead for believers' hope
questions.explanation: Acts 13:32-34 explains that God fulfilled the promise to the fathers by raising Jesus from the dead, encouraging believers to trust God's faithfulness.

questions.question: What does Acts 13 teach about the importance of rejoicing and being filled with the Holy Spirit in the life of disciples?
options: Disciples are filled with joy and the Holy Spirit even amid challenges
Disciples should be somber and avoid joy
The Holy Spirit only fills leaders, not all disciples
Joy is unrelated to the Spirit's work
questions.correctAnswer: Disciples are filled with joy and the Holy Spirit even amid challenges
questions.explanation: Acts 13:52 states that the disciples were filled with joy and the Holy Ghost, indicating the Spirit's role in sustaining believers through trials.

questions.question: How does Acts 13 teach about God's justice and righteousness when confronting opposition and falsehood?
options: God's hand brings correction and exposes evil, as shown in Elymas' blindness
God ignores opposition and allows falsehood to prevail
Believers should respond with violence to opposition
questions.correctAnswer: God's hand brings correction and exposes evil, as shown in Elymas' blindness
questions.explanation: Acts 13:8-11 describes Elymas the sorcerer opposing the Gospel and being struck blind by God's power, illustrating divine justice confronting evil.

hard.title: Acts Chapter 13 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Acts Chapter 13.

questions.question: Who were the prophets and teachers mentioned as being in the church at Antioch?
options: Barnabas, Simeon called Niger, Lucius of Cyrene, Manaen, and Saul
questions.correctAnswer: Barnabas, Simeon called Niger, Lucius of Cyrene, Manaen, and Saul
questions.explanation: Acts 13:1 lists those prophets and teachers in the Antioch church specifically as Barnabas, Simeon called Niger, Lucius of Cyrene, Manaen, and Saul.

questions.question: What directive did the Holy Ghost give while the church at Antioch was ministering and fasting?
options: Separate Barnabas and Saul for the work He has called them to
Anoint Peter as the leader of the church
Send out Paul and Silas to Jerusalem
Fast for forty days and pray for guidance
questions.correctAnswer: Separate Barnabas and Saul for the work He has called them to
questions.explanation: In Acts 13:2, the Holy Ghost specifically commanded to separate Barnabas and Saul for the work He had called them to do.

questions.question: Where did Barnabas and Saul sail to after departing Seleucia?
questions.correctAnswer: Cyprus
questions.explanation: Acts 13:4 states that after departing from Seleucia, Barnabas and Saul sailed to Cyprus.

questions.question: Who was the sorcerer and false prophet encountered by Paul and Barnabas in Paphos?
questions.correctAnswer: Barjesus
questions.explanation: Acts 13:6-7 introduces Barjesus as the sorcerer and false prophet in Paphos, associated with Sergius Paulus.

questions.question: What was the response of Elymas the sorcerer when Barnabas and Saul tried to preach to Sergius Paulus?
options: He withstood them, seeking to turn away the deputy from the faith
He accepted the gospel and repented immediately
He fled the city in fear
He became a disciple and helper
questions.correctAnswer: He withstood them, seeking to turn away the deputy from the faith
questions.explanation: Acts 13:8 describes Elymas opposing Barnabas and Saul to prevent Sergius Paulus from believing.

questions.question: What punishment did Paul pronounce on Elymas the sorcerer?
options: He would be blinded for a season
He would be struck dead immediately
He would be cast out of the city
questions.correctAnswer: He would be blinded for a season
questions.explanation: Acts 13:11 states that Paul declared Elymas would be blind for a time, and immediately a mist and darkness came upon him.

questions.question: Why did Sergius Paulus believe after witnessing Paul's action against Elymas?
options: He was astonished at the doctrine of the Lord
He was convinced by the synagogue rulers
He had a vision of an angel
questions.correctAnswer: He was astonished at the doctrine of the Lord
questions.explanation: Acts 13:12 explains that Sergius Paulus believed because he was amazed by the teaching about the Lord after Elymas was struck blind.

questions.question: What significant event took place in the synagogue at Antioch in Pisidia on the Sabbath?
options: Paul stood up to preach the word of exhortation
Barnabas was chosen as the high priest
The law of Moses was rewritten
questions.correctAnswer: Paul stood up to preach the word of exhortation
questions.explanation: Acts 13:14-16 describes Paul standing up in the synagogue after the reading of the law and prophets to deliver an exhortation.

questions.question: Which Old Testament king does Paul reference as 'a man after God's own heart'?
questions.correctAnswer: David
questions.explanation: Acts 13:22 quotes God’s testimony that David was a man after His own heart who would fulfill all His will.

questions.question: According to Paul’s sermon in Acts 13, who is the promised Savior raised from the seed of David?
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus
questions.explanation: Acts 13:23 declares that God raised up Jesus, descended from David's seed, as the promised Savior of Israel.

questions.question: How does Paul use Psalm 2 in his sermon to support Jesus’ resurrection?
options: He cites it as proof that God declared Jesus His Son on the day of resurrection
He claims it foretells Jesus’ birth in Bethlehem
He interprets it as a warning to the Jews
He uses it to explain the coming of the Holy Spirit
questions.correctAnswer: He cites it as proof that God declared Jesus His Son on the day of resurrection
questions.explanation: Acts 13:33 references Psalm 2, where God says 'Thou art my Son; this day have I begotten thee,' linking it to Jesus’ resurrection.

questions.question: What theological contrast does Paul draw between David and Jesus in terms of corruption?
options: David saw corruption after death, but Jesus did not
Both David and Jesus saw corruption
Neither David nor Jesus saw corruption
Jesus saw corruption, but David did not
questions.correctAnswer: David saw corruption after death, but Jesus did not
questions.explanation: Acts 13:36-37 contrasts David’s body seeing corruption after death with Jesus, who was raised and did not see corruption.

questions.question: What is preached through Jesus according to Paul’s message in Acts 13?
options: The power of the Roman Empire
questions.correctAnswer: The forgiveness of sins
questions.explanation: Acts 13:38 states that through Jesus, forgiveness of sins is preached to the listeners.

questions.question: What reaction did the Jews have when many Gentiles came to hear the word of God?
options: They were filled with envy and contradicted Paul
They joined the Gentiles in praise
questions.correctAnswer: They were filled with envy and contradicted Paul
questions.explanation: Acts 13:45 describes the Jews being envious and speaking against Paul’s message, contradicting and blaspheming it.

questions.question: True or False: Paul and Barnabas decided to focus their ministry on the Gentiles after the Jews rejected the word of God.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Acts 13:46 records Paul and Barnabas boldly declaring that since the Jews rejected the word, they would turn to the Gentiles.

theological.title: Acts Chapter 13 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Acts Chapter 13 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: Who were the individuals mentioned as prophets and teachers in the church at Antioch?
options: Barnabas, Simeon called Niger, Lucius of Cyrene, Manaen, and Saul
questions.correctAnswer: Barnabas, Simeon called Niger, Lucius of Cyrene, Manaen, and Saul
questions.explanation: Acts 13:1 explicitly lists Barnabas, Simeon called Niger, Lucius of Cyrene, Manaen, and Saul as prophets and teachers in the Antioch church. This reflects the early church's diverse leadership as seen in 1 Corinthians 12:28 and Ephesians 4:11.

questions.question: What was the Spirit's command to the church during their fasting and prayer in Antioch?
options: Separate Barnabas and Saul for the work to which He called them
Send Peter and John to Jerusalem
Build a new church in Cyprus
Pray for the salvation of the Gentiles
questions.correctAnswer: Separate Barnabas and Saul for the work to which He called them
questions.explanation: Acts 13:2 records the Holy Ghost instructing the church to separate Barnabas and Saul for a special mission, indicating the Spirit's active role in commissioning ministry, consistent with Jesus' sending of the disciples in John 20:21 and the Spirit's empowerment in Acts 1:8.

questions.question: Where did Paul and Barnabas first travel after being sent out by the Holy Spirit?
questions.correctAnswer: Seleucia and then Cyprus
questions.explanation: Acts 13:4 states that Paul and Barnabas, sent by the Holy Spirit, departed to Seleucia and then sailed to Cyprus. This reflects the missionary expansion beyond Jewish centers as foretold in Isaiah 49:6 and fulfilled in the Great Commission (Matthew 28:19).

questions.question: Who accompanied Paul and Barnabas as their minister during their preaching in Salamis?
questions.correctAnswer: John
questions.explanation: Acts 13:5 indicates that John was their minister during their preaching in Salamis. This shows the early church's team ministry approach, echoed in Paul's later letters where companions support the apostolic mission (Philippians 2:25).

questions.question: What was the name and occupation of the man who opposed Paul and Barnabas in Paphos?
options: Elymas, a sorcerer and false prophet
questions.correctAnswer: Elymas, a sorcerer and false prophet
questions.explanation: Acts 13:6-8 identifies Elymas as a sorcerer and false prophet who opposed the gospel, seeking to turn the deputy from the faith. This confrontation highlights the conflict between divine truth and spiritual deception, reminiscent of Old Testament prophets confronting false prophets (1 Kings 18:20-40).

questions.question: What happened to Elymas when Paul, filled with the Holy Spirit, confronted him?
options: He was struck with temporary blindness
questions.correctAnswer: He was struck with temporary blindness
questions.explanation: Acts 13:9-11 recounts that Paul, filled with the Holy Spirit, pronounced judgment on Elymas, causing him to be temporarily blind, illustrating God's sovereign judgment against opposition to the gospel, paralleling Old Testament judgments like that of Saul's blinding in 1 Samuel 14:27.

questions.question: What was the reaction of Sergius Paulus, the deputy, after witnessing Elymas's blindness?
options: He believed, amazed at the teaching about the Lord
He ordered Elymas to be healed immediately
questions.correctAnswer: He believed, amazed at the teaching about the Lord
questions.explanation: Acts 13:12 shows Sergius Paulus believing after seeing the miracle, displaying how divine signs confirm the gospel message, consistent with the healing miracles in the Gospels leading to faith (John 9:38).

questions.question: Which city did Paul and Barnabas visit after leaving Perga in Pamphylia?
questions.correctAnswer: Antioch in Pisidia
questions.explanation: Acts 13:14 records their arrival at Antioch in Pisidia, where they preached in the synagogue, continuing the pattern of evangelizing Jewish synagogues as starting points for the gospel (Luke 4:16-21).

questions.question: What was the subject of Paul’s sermon in the synagogue at Antioch in Pisidia?
options: God’s faithfulness in history culminating in Jesus as Savior
The necessity of strict adherence to the Mosaic Law
The superiority of the Temple sacrifices
The coming of the end times exclusively
questions.correctAnswer: God’s faithfulness in history culminating in Jesus as Savior
questions.explanation: Acts 13:16-37 reveals Paul’s sermon tracing Israel’s history from the exodus, judges, kings, to Jesus as the promised Savior, highlighting God's redemptive plan, consistent with Old Testament messianic prophecies (Isaiah 53) and New Testament fulfillment (Luke 24:27).

questions.question: According to Paul’s sermon, who is the 'man after God's own heart'?
questions.correctAnswer: David
questions.explanation: Acts 13:22 identifies David as the man after God's own heart, to whom God gave testimony, establishing the messianic lineage culminating in Jesus, fulfilling promises like 2 Samuel 7 and Psalm 2 about the king and Son of God.

questions.question: What does Acts 13 teach about Jesus' resurrection and its significance?
options: Jesus was raised from the dead, fulfilling God's promises and ensuring forgiveness and justification
Jesus remained in the grave, awaiting the final judgment
Jesus' resurrection was a metaphorical event
Only select disciples witnessed the resurrection
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus was raised from the dead, fulfilling God's promises and ensuring forgiveness and justification
questions.explanation: Acts 13:30-39 emphasizes Jesus’ bodily resurrection as fulfillment of God's promises, confirming him as Savior through whom forgiveness and justification are offered, aligning with Romans 4:25 and 1 Corinthians 15:17.

questions.question: How does Paul describe the effect of faith in Jesus compared to the law of Moses?
options: By Jesus, all who believe are justified from all things, which the law could not justify
Faith in Jesus adds to the law but does not replace it
The law alone justifies without faith
Faith in Jesus is irrelevant without strict law observance
questions.correctAnswer: By Jesus, all who believe are justified from all things, which the law could not justify
questions.explanation: Acts 13:38-39 teaches justification by faith in Jesus apart from the law, a core Pauline doctrine seen also in Galatians 2:16 and Romans 3:28, highlighting the insufficiency of the law for salvation.

questions.question: What prophetic warning does Paul give to the listeners in Acts 13?
options: Beware lest the prophecy about despisers who wonder and perish come upon you
Obey all laws strictly to avoid punishment
questions.correctAnswer: Beware lest the prophecy about despisers who wonder and perish come upon you
questions.explanation: Acts 13:40-41 quotes prophecy warning those who despise God's work will perish, echoing Old Testament themes of judgment on unbelief (Psalm 2:1-3; Isaiah 29:13), underscoring the seriousness of rejecting the gospel.

questions.question: What was the response of the Gentiles after hearing the gospel at Antioch?
options: They were glad and glorified the word of the Lord
They persecuted Paul and Barnabas immediately
questions.correctAnswer: They were glad and glorified the word of the Lord
questions.explanation: Acts 13:48-49 describes the Gentiles' positive reception to the gospel, glorifying God and believing, illustrating God's inclusive plan of salvation as foretold in Isaiah 49:6 and revealed in Romans 10:12.

questions.question: What action did the Jews take against Paul and Barnabas after many believed?
options: They stirred up persecution and expelled them from their region
They invited them to teach in the temple
questions.correctAnswer: They stirred up persecution and expelled them from their region
questions.explanation: Acts 13:50-51 records the Jews inciting persecution against Paul and Barnabas, leading to their expulsion, exemplifying the opposition early Christians faced, consistent with Jesus’ warning in John 15:20 and the persecution of prophets in the Old Testament (Jeremiah 20:2).
